Description: Rim fragment of Attic black-figured pottery dinos. On the top, compass-drawn rosettes with traces of added colour. On the exterior of the rim added red applied directly to the clay. Interior glossy black with added red band at bottom edge of the lip.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Venit: 'Sophilos. For the narrow petals of the rosettes, the compass-incised circles (including those that delimit the outside of the rosette), and the large centres painted red compare Louvre E 873 (ABV 39, 12; AthMitt 62 [1937] pl. 54 fig. 2) and Heraklion (Paralipomena 18, 14, bis; ASAtene 33-34 [n.s. 17-18] [1955-56] 46 fig. 1; Bakir pl. 80 fig. 158). According to D. Williams (letter: 11 March 1987) not part of London B 100, London B 601.26 (ABV 39, 13; JHS 49 [1929] 257 figs. 4-5, pl. 17 fig. 8), or Reading 26.ii.1 (ABV 41, 34; CVA Great Britain 12: pl. 23 fig. 40), which Beazley (Hesperia 13 [1944] 51 no. 30) suggested might belong together and which have been joined by Williams ("Sophilos in the British Museum," Greek Vases in the J. Paul Getty Museum [Occasional Papers on Antiquities 1; Malibu, 1983] 34 and 32 fig. 35). Possibly part of same dinos as Cambridge, Museum of Classical Archaeology N 128 (ABV 39, 14; CVA Great Britain 11: pl. 21 fig. 33), which is mising its rim.'
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 79 no. 265 pl. 60)
Venit 1984 / Early Attic Black Figure Vases in Egypt (p. 149 fig. 16)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.1198)
